IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: TO HELP HOMELESS AND RUNAWAY YOUTH EXIT LIFE ON THE STREETS.
IRS990.MissionDescription: FOUNDED IN 1984, LARKIN STREET YOUTH SERVICES (LARKIN STREET) IS A COMMUNITY-BASED NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION DEDICATED TO HELPING HOMELESS, RUNAWAY, AND AT-RISK YOUTH IN SAN FRANCISCO FIND HEALTHY AND LASTING ALTERNATIVES TO STREET LIFE. LARKIN STREET IS A NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED CONTINUUM OF YOUTH-CENTERED SERVICES DESIGNED TO SUPPORT A YOUNG PERSON'S PERMANENT TRANSITION FROM STREET LIFE TO INDEPENDENCE.
IRS990.Description: LARKIN STREET OPERATES TWELVE DISTINCT HOUSING PROGRAMS AND PROVIDES EXTENSIVE STREET OUTREACH SERVICE, WRAP-AROUND CASE MANAGEMENT, HEALTH CARE (INCLUDING MENTAL HEALTH, SUBSTANCE ABUSE, HIV PREVENTION AND TREATMENT) AND EDUCATION AND EMPLOYMENT SUPPORT. IN 2009-2010, LARKIN STREET SERVED OVER 3,438 HOMELESS AND RUNAWAY YOUTH BETWEEN THE AGES OF 12 AND 24 THROUGH OUR ONSITE PROGRAMS, AND MADE OVER 11,038 OUTREACH CONTACTS ON THE STREETS OF SAN FRANCISCO. THE AGENCY'S DISTINCTIVE MODEL OF CARE BUILDS ON AND ACKNOWLEDGES THE STRENGTHS AND ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF YOUTH AND CELEBRATES THEIR ACHIEVEMENTS. THE INTEGRATION OF CRISIS INTERVENTION, HOUSING, REHABILITATION AND SUPPORTIVE SERVICES HAS BEEN EXTREMELY SUCCESSFUL IN BREAKING THE CYCLE OF HOMELESSNESS: 76% OF YOUNG PEOPLE WHO COMPLETE OUR COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMS SUCCESSFULLY LEAVE STREET LIFE PERMANENTLY.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Financial Accounting Standards Board issued new guidance on accounting for uncertainty in income taxes. Larkin Street adopted this new guidance for the year ended June 30, 2010. Management evaluated Larkin Street's tax positions and concluded that Larkin Street had maintained its tax exempt status and had taken no uncertain tax positions that require adjustment to the financial statements. Therefore, no provision or liability for income taxes has been included in the financial statements.

EventsInformation.NameOfEvent2: BAY AREA CFO OF THE YEAR AWARDS

RecipientNameBusiness.BusinessNameLine1: San Francisco General Hospital Medical Ctr

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Book Scholarship Hire Up provided book scholarships up to $150 for Fall 2009 and $200 for Spring 2010 semester, to youth registered for college classes. Awards were on a first-come, first-served basis and the amount was determined from a book quote form provided by the college bookstore. The scholarship checks are made out to the postsecondary institution bookstore. In order to receive the scholarship, students must complete a Hire Up Assessment and interested students should attend a College Success workshop to meet with an Education Specialist and submit: A completed Hire Up Scholarship Application A copy of their school registration A price quote form, obtained from the college bookstore The books scholarship can be renewed every semester. For renewals, the youth must have met with college counseling staff or attended workshops at least three times throughout the semester, completed the semester with a 2.00 GPA, and submit a receipt. College Success Scholarship As an incentive for youth to attend college success groups, those who enroll in class, attend a specified number of groups, and pass the semester with at least a 2.00 GPA are eligible to earn a scholarship of up to $150 per semester, and up to $50 for the summer semester. The amount varies on the number of workshops/individual check-ins attended. Other requirements include: Completing a Hire Up Assessment (if they have not already done so) Completing the Hire Up Scholarship Application Submitting their final grades College Access Foundation of California Scholarship The College Access Foundation of California (CAFC) scholarship provides financial support and supportive services that allow youth to enroll in school full-time and succeed academically. The scholarship is aimed toward first time students who have obtained a High School Diploma or Equivalent in the state of California and are enrolled in an undergraduate program. Youth are eligible to receive up to $5,000 ($2,500 per semester) and the amount awarded is based on the unmet need provided by the postsecondary institution. The awarded amount is reported to the financial aid office. To be eligible for the CAFC scholarship, candidates must: Enroll in college full-time Complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) Complete a Hire Up scholarship application and submit personal statement, transcripts, and class registration Have unmet need reported by the financial aid office In terms of programming, youth must complete at least three check-ins/workshops for each month of the semester (a total of 12) with the Educational Specialists, provide mid-term and semester grades, and partake in college success workshops or tutoring should their academic situation dictate it. Youth must maintain above a 2.00 GPA. National Youth Employment Coalition Postsecondary Success Initiative The NYEC PSI provides youth with resources and services for preparation, persistence and attainment in postsecondary education. Through funding from the PSI youth are eligible to receive a book or tuition scholarships that are similar in structure to the scholarship mentioned above. Youth are eligible to receive up to $5,000 ($2,500 per semester) and the amount awarded is based on the unmet need provided by the postsecondary institution. The awarded amount is reported to the financial aid office. To be eligible for the NYEC PSI scholarship, candidates must: Enroll in college full-time Complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) Complete a Hire Up scholarship application and submit personal statement, transcripts, and class registration Have unmet need reported by the financial aid office In terms of programming, youth must complete at least three check-ins/workshops for each month of the semester (a total of 12) with the Educational Specialists, provide mid-term and semester grades, and partake in college success workshops or tutoring should their academic situation dictate it. Youth must maintain above a 2.00 GPA. Art Scholarship The Debbie Jorgenson Art Scholarship has been established to provide financial assistance to one youth per year who have the passion, desire and motivation to pursue a formal art education and need financial assistance to assist with reaching that goal. Youth are eligible to receive funding to assist with tuition/registration, supplies and transportation expenses. To apply for the scholarship, candidates must: Be engaged in Larkin Street Services for a minimum of six months Completion of High School or GED Demonstrated commitment to completion of his/her goals Ability and willingness to follow through with Art Program Youth submit a short essay about why they should receive the scholarship and include goals for the next six months as well as their ultimate goal. The youth receives the scholarship funding directly and is required to save 30% of the scholarship, which is awarded as a completion bonus at the end of the scholarship program. Youth must maintain above a 2.00 GPA.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Identifier: Method for Determining Number of Contributors:
Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: the number of contributors is based on the number of donors, not the number of items contributed.

Stock gifts are received into one of three financial institutions. Upon receipt of the gift, the financial institutions liquidate the stock and transfer the funds to the organization's operating account.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE TAXPAYER'S ACCOUNTING FIRM FORWARDED THE FORM 990 TO THE CFO, who reviews and then forwards THE FORM 990 TO THE board members FOR THEIR REVIEW PRIOR TO FILING THE FORM 990. board MEMBERS aRE ENCOURAGED TO REVIEW THE FORM 990 AND TO FORWARD THEIR QUESTIONS TO THE CFO. EITHER THE CFO OR THE ACCOUNTING FIRM ADDRESSEs THE QUESTIONS FROM THE board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: LARKIN STREET YOUTH SERVICES REQUIRES BOARD AND SENIOR MANAGEMENT TO DISCLOSE POTENTIAL CONFLICTS OF INTEREST. THE FINANCE DEPARTMENT MONITORS SPENDING AND CONTRACTS THROUGHOUT THE YEAR TO eNSURE COMPLIANCE.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: SALARIES ORIGINALLY SET BY THE BOARD LED ANALYSIS OF SALARIES WITHIN SECTOR, INCLUDING REVIEW OF SURVEYS AND COMPARABLE POSITIONS. INCREASES HAVE FOLLOWED AGENCY POLICY FOR MERIT INCREASES- RANKINGS WITHIN THE AGENCY PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM EARN STAFF A 0-3% MERIT RAISE.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE ORGANIZATION MAKES ITS FINANCIAL STATEMENTS and Tax Returns AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST OR ON THE ATTORNEY GENERAL'S WEBSITE, WHILE THE CONFLICT OF INTEREST IS MADE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.

The organization has a committee that assumes responsibility for the oversight of the audit and the selection of an independent accountant. The role of audit committee has not changed since prior year.
